author: EThreeZone

description.text: Il Drone FTS.01 é stato progettato disegnato e costruito da FromTheSky (il nome sta per From The Sky Esemplare 01). La meccanica e l’elettronica sono state studiate e realizzate pensando all’utilizzo nell’ambito della fotografia metrica e della scansione 3D in grande scala. La programmazione dell’unità inerziale basata su APM (ma anche questa ottimizzata internamente,) consente di effettuare riprese e fotografie anche in situazioni difficili e con scarsa o assente visibilità, grazie al sistema “Fly By Waypoints”. Le dimensioni “generose” (1,6mt di diametro) e l’utilizzo del più pregiato carbonio aeronautico fornito da CETMA Composites garantiscono al FTS.01 una elevata capacità di carico e un payload di tre volte superiore rispetto alla concorrenza. FTS.01 è un prodotto artigianale, ma sviluppato con le tecniche più avanzate di stampa 3D e taglio Laser
Il Drone è completo, già collaudato. questo articolo verrà integrato prestissimo di tutto il necessario per essere riprodotto senza difficoltà da chiunque

title: PCB assembly forming plate for surface mounted devices (SMD)

description.text:
Up to now, there were only component lead benders for through-the-hole components.
  • Using your 3D printer, you can have this now even for SMDs, making manual prototype assembly or component-level repair of SMDs much easier!
  • All SMD components can be bent uniformly and consistently. Bender would be proud!
  • The most common package shapes and sizes are included, together with their codes on the side of the tool.
    • Thanks go out to steve6330, who created the nice PCB-AssemblingFormerPlate, which was the basis for this tool. Update V3: Now it works without any additional libraries.
Print it 1:1, no supports needed.

comments.text: Missing 2 libs - 'Write/Write.scad and module 'writecube'
comments.author: geoff_cohen

comments.text: I updated the file - now you don't need any library anymore to customize it for your use.
comments.author: geoff_cohen

comments.text: Ive looked at this for about 10 minutes and have no clue what this is. How do you bend SMD components and why would you want to do that? Its not like you can bend the pins and use it in a pinch for a through hole component. I have no idea what purpose this has, maybe to identify package sizes but why 3D print a gadget for that when you can print it out on a sheet of paper. I dont know, this seems completely useless to me.
comments.author: IamTeknik

comments.text: It all depends on your workflow. For some, SMD soldering is harder than through hole component soldering. With this tool, you can prepare the SMD components to make placing and soldering much easier. Its only useful if you solder SMD by hand. In the next revision, i might do an auto-bend mechanism as well.
comments.author: IamTeknik

comments.text: It still doesnt make sense... You dont need to prepare SMD parts, you place solder and solder it onto the pad. Please explain how this tool actually works and what are you even bending? How can you bend an SMD cap or resistor???
comments.author: makkuro

comments.text: You don't have to prepare the parts, its optional. Depending on the manufacturing process, some SMD parts might not need the preparation to fit.
comments.author: IamTeknik

comments.text: Wow dude, what the heck is preparation???!! You buy an smd part and solder it on. There is no need to bend legs, mostly because there arent any, and you dont need a holder for it. You take it out the package and reflow solder it or hand solder. I doubt any one who has looked at this device has any idea what its for.
comments.author: makkuro

comments.text:
Good point. Another angle is Poka Yoke: Try to avoid issues e.g. while soldering by using technical solutions. So this can help here, exactly when you have to prepare a soldering session or are unsatisfied with the parts you got. Several people i know have the tool now in their standard soldering equipment. And when somebody sees my tool, they want one for themselves. Checkout also the number of collectors for this model above (more than 100 at this point).
As this tool is inspired by Kaizen, if you have any improvement suggestions, i would be happy to implement them.

description.text:
Little Bell is a modern chandelier with a beautiful soft light and shadows. Its design is inspired by music symbol "key SOL".
We made it in our summer school "Villa Pennisi in Musica 2013" - http://vpmusica.com
The goal of this project was to create a personal light to the italian pianist M° Campanella for its concert night, in Villa Pennisi, Sicily.
You could see us at work, watching our documentary here on Vimeo: http://vimeo.com/93459032

You need a printer with real 200x200mm print area.
Print all the sectors without infill, with 1 perimeter.
There are 4 different up sectors, you have to print 4 time all of them.
Print 12 bottom sectors.
Print 12 sectors holders to clip to the inside the 12 bottom sectors.
Print 1 lamp holder.
Buy a "lamp holder" for the bulb.

Edit: Use the \"Rv4.STL\" version!
Edit: For more print and assembly pictures http://makerblock.com/2010/08/3x2x1-rubiks-cube-assembly-pictures Want to read more about this design? Do you want me to make one for you? Check out my blog at http://www.MakerBlock.com NO TOOLS, NO HARDWARE, just print, clean, and assemble!!! This is similar to prior iterations of this 3x2x1 Rubik\'s-style puzzle cube - except it is intended to be a 100% printable, no hardware required design. It is inspired by: TomZ\'s 1x2x3 \"Friendlier\" Rubik\'s Cube, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412
and
R3becca\'s Beco Block connecting mechanism, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1983 TomZ\'s original 1x2x3 puzzle was a totally printable design - but it required a peg that had to be glued in place. This means once assembled it couldn\'t easily be taken apart for cleaning, repair, etc. The X-ray screenshot should pretty well show the barbell connector as well as the connector mechanism. Both parts are similar to R3becca\'s own connector system - especially the barbell. However, the interior cube connector is a simplified version of her female connector - simply because it was too hard for me to replicate her designs. :) This version comes with a single STL for all parts: 2 identical center cubes, 4 identical edge cubes, and a single \"barbell\connector for the middle. I\'m leaving the initial version in case you want to play with it. I\'ve actually printed the last version, \"Rv4.STL\". I\'ve also done a better job of placing the parts and centering the entire set. Before you had to make sure your print head was exactly centered before you could try printing it. Now you should have far more wiggle room on any side.

• Print all parts as a single \"production\" file. <Nod to Cryozap http://www.thingiverse.com/cyrozap>
  • Clean parts.
  • Slot two end cube pieces (with semi-circular tabs) into the two semi-circular holes in each center cube piece.
  • Pop the small flat tabs off the center barbell connector.
  • Pop one end of the barbell into the center of either center center cube piece.
  • Spin and rotate to loosen parts.

comments.text: I'm glad you like it!  Which pieces were a little loose for you?  I basically modeled it so that all the pieces have 0.5mm clearance or so.  This allowed my pieces to fit together snugly and loosen a little with use.  I've printed two (and a half) sets of this model and I've been able to hand-press the pins in each time.  Perhaps this is a slight variation in Skeinforge settings or Z axis alignment?  It will go together a lot easier after the first few times you pull it apart to show people the insides.   ;)

comments.text: Oh, and the first version I left here will be significantly looser than the final version I uploaded.

comments.text: I am interested in trying your gcode, how did you generate it? How well does it minimize strings between the printed parts? I'll look at is to see how it starts and the temp...
comments.author: owenscenic

comments.text: @Owenscenic: That Gcode is for ABS printing at 220C on a raft, generated using RepGv18. There were very few strings between parts when I printed this. I positioned the pieces in the STL to help minimize stringing too. Check out the pictures on my blog for more detailed shots.

title: Piston wrist pin for W16 engine

title: Governor linkage end, ball joint for MEP-002A and MEP-003A military diesel generators.

description.text:
Ball joint rod end (socket only) to fit the governor linkage on the MEP-002A and MEP-003A military diesel generators.  
This is not exactly a remix, it is all my own work, but before creating it I decided to look on thingiverse first, and sure enough there it was.  However my slic3r would not add correct support under the overhang, and only the .stl was availiable.  So in the end I had to recreate it myself anyway.  I left one side flat so that it can be printed with no support.  Thanks to  Mrcleanr6 for his version though.

See the comments in the .scad file, at the top.  
Mine pressed on hard, had to use a small arbor press to put the joint together.  It later loosened up nice, see comments.

author: terrym

title: Dual E3D V6 - Independently Height Adjustable Mount for Rostock Max V2

description.text:
This is a mount for dual E3D V6 hotends for the SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V2. I believe it will also fit the V1. One of the hotends is height adjustable for ease of leveling. Included is a single fan shroud. Offset along the Y-Axis only.
Required hardware:
3 x 10mm M3 Pan Head Screws (you could also use socket head I suppose, it doesn't really matter)
3 x M3 Nylon Lock Nuts
3 x 15-20mm M3 Socket Head Cap Screws
3 x M3 Nuts

Fit one of the assembled hotends into Mount1.STL, align with Top.STL, then mount to the effector using 3 Socket Head Cap Screws and 3 Nylon Lock Nuts. Install the screws from the bottom, such that the lock nuts are on the top side.
Fit 3 M3 nuts into the captive holes of Mount2.STL.
Fit the second assembled hotend into Mount2.STL, then from the bottom, mount Mount2.STL to Top.STL using 3 10mm Pan Head screws. It's a tight fit, but it's manageable.
Finally, just clip the fan shroud in place, and you should be done!

description.text: Periodic bathymetry tiles, interior has been hollowed out to allow insertion of metal bars (as ballast) and instrumentation. This is intended for use in fluid dynamic demonstrations and experiments, for example at the bottom of http://paoc.mit.edu/labguide/apparatus.html. Small openings in top surface allow for air to escape the hollowed interior and sensors to be inserted in the flow. Both *.stl and the OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/) source files are included, please modify the generating function to suit your needs.

The openscad file generates bathymetry as given by a product of cosines but any arbitrary bathymetry can be used if the zxy function
function zxy(xi,yj) = 2+cos(xi360/10.)cos(yj*360/10.);
is changed. Alternatively you can remove the comment "//" on the line using zz[i][j]
// bathy([zz[j][i],zz[j][i+1],zz[j+1][i+1],zz[j+1][i]],thesize);
and comment out the line using zxy(x,y) bathy([zxy(x[i],y[j]),zxy(x[i+1],y[j]),zxy(x[i+1],y[j+1]),zxy(x[i],y[j+1])],thesize);
and the bathymetry is given by the zz matrix.

comments.text: "Bathymetry is the study of underwater depth of lake or ocean floors. In other words, bathymetry is the underwater equivalent to hypsometry or topography." see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bathymetryhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B...

description.text:
These are smaller versions of thing:37006 Translucent Snowflake Ornament.  They are done in natural ABS and the decorations are simple and are well handled by my Replicator.
The ornaments are 40 mm in diameter and are sized to fit over an inexpensive LED tea light.  A small rotating LED turntable can also be used.  The image at the upper left shows an ornament placed on a tea light.
Two versions are given:
Ornament_Xmas_2012.stl   which has Xmas 2012 on the top, and  3 different snowflakes on the sides.
Desk_Ornament.stl        which has a pattern based on plane group p6, a Sierpinski triangle, and a pattern based on the p4m plane group
It is difficult to get a good picture of the ornaments, one image at the upper left is a composite of the faces of ornament_xmas_2012 lit by a blue LED.

The ornaments take less than an hour to print.  They  print most quickly if placed directly on the build platform. I used one shell and 5% infill.
They look best when illuminated with a bright blue LED but almost any tea light works if the ornament is placed in a dimly lit area.
Desk_Ornament.scad generates the ornaments.  It requires two include files: Patterns.scad and ArchitectsDaughter.scad.  ArchitectsDaughter.scad is one of Polymakers fonts - see thing:13677.  The font file generates error messages during execution which can be ignored.

title: (moved) Parametric, dual angle Nexus 7 stand

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/parametric-dual-angle-nexus-7-stand Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html I wanted a wider stand because the headphone-cable tends to pull the tablet to one side and
I wanted a second viewing angle for narrow train/airplane tables.
...so I made a parametric stand to make these things changable. Blog posting:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/12/parametric-tablet-stand.html

Parameters:

  • "total_width" the total width of the stand of cause.
    Change this to made a wider or smaller stand.
    I attached a long and a short version of this stand.

  • "total_length" same for the length
  • "total_height"
  • "front angle" how slanted the tablet stands using the front slot (default 70ÃÂ°)

  • "back_angle" how slanted the tablet stands using the back slot (default 45ÃÂ°)

  • "thickness" thickness in front of the screen
  • "tablet thickness" thickness of the slot for the tablet

The Disneyland Skyway was a gondola lift transportation system from Tomorrowland to Fantasyland and back. It also took people through the Matterhorn on its way to Fantasyland. The lift always had the perfect areal view of the park from every angle and many of the Disneyland areal photos were taken from them. Simply print out the lifts and however many track pieces you may need. Then tie some string between two or more track pieces on both sides and put your liftson the string.

author: warrior1465

title: Replicator Cold Air Intake Kit (no cutting)

description.text:
This kit redirects the motherboard cooling intake to the side of the machine to draw in cool air instead of warm air from inside the printer.  This works with the $15 Replicator Enclosure.  Or, optionally download the manifold with no flange for a cleaner looking intake port.
Hopefully this will save some voltage regulators from failing.

• Print out the manifold and duct with supports and carefully remove the supports from inside the manifold with needle nose pliers.

  • Use a file to widen the intake manifold slots until it is big enough to fit in the Replicator corner window.

  • You may have to use diagonal cutters to remove a notch from the fan duct where it meets the triangular hole in the replicator floor for cable clearance.

  • Use your "print remover" to loosen the double-stick tape used for the Y-axis cable guide and reposition it about 1 inch higher.

  • Install the intake manifold.

  • Remove the Replicator bottom cover and remove the fan bolts. The fan stand-offs will not be used.

  • Re-install the motherboard fan using the new fan duct.

  • If you are using the $15 replicator enclosure, you will have to cut a notch to match the slots in the intake manifold.
I uploaded a no flange version of the manifold for a cleaner look.  If anybody has any suggestions for modifications, let me know and I'll see what I can do.

text = this belongs to Keegan !

The Z stage of the Thing-o-Matic has 2 unused mounting holes in the back.
Yet it only supports it's heavy extruder from the left and right using long levers. When transporting the ToM in a vibrating vessel, maybe even non-upright, there is lots of stress on these tiny bolts.
(Think of having it on it's back in the overhead compartment of a train.) So I'm testing this to support the extruder stepper from the back with a third "dino". Blog-posting:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/12/thing-o-matic-3rd-dino.html
You may insert M5 bolts with a bit of force or cut proper threads into plastic and Z-stage and insert M6 bolts to hold super-tight.

I made this template to cut out holes to install USB ports into custom built furniture.  I use an inlay kit that has a 1/8" spiral downcut bit with a 5/16" OD bushing.  The insert can be rotated to accommodate dual USB ports.  Is still requires a little cleanup with a micro file or exacto knife, but that's because I don't have a square router bit.

This is a car Dock for my Motorola Droid.  I couldn't find the right one in a store or online, so I designed my own and printed it.  If you have a 2003 Mazda Tribute, then you are in luck.  Otherwise you will need to adapt it to fit your car.  My car has a little pocket that the dock wedges into nicely.  The clamp ring helped to take the complexity out of the biggest part to ensure a smooth print.  The little 1/8" dia x 1/4" long magnet tells the Droid to automatically go to Car mode.  If you reverser the magnet, then it will go to the other dock mode which is more of an alarm clock look.

Modify to fit your car
Print
Assemble
Navigate

comments.text: I used super glue (cyanoacrylate) to join the sides with the base.  I did not have acetone to make ABS glue, but I would assume that it would work better than cyanoacrylate.  There is very little force on those joints.  Most of the force is on the joint between the base and the ball. It hasn't broken yet  :)

title: Bamboo Biological Enclosure Center Part1 of 2

description.text:
Team Engineering Challenge:
Construct a biological enclosure
in 7 minutes using plastic parts and precut bamboo, This bilogical enclosure can be used to support mosquito netting and may help combat the spread of malaria in countries with restricted economies and open borders. Part 1 of 2: Center Piece:
Creates tension from 4 corners with string to help keep base of bamboo enclosure stable and "squared". Part 2 of 2: Corner Piece:
Secures bamboo pieces in corners to create a base and allows two arching bamboo pieces to form a dome from which to hang mosquito netting

Download both parts of the project. Print out both pieces. One center piece and four corner pieces should be printed. Select four bamboos two centimeters in diameter for wedges in corner piece. 2 pieces of bamboo should be 6 feet in length and other two pieces should be 8 feet in length for optimal stability (for the base of the enclosure). Select four additional bamboo pieces one centimeter in diameter for hole in corner piece. Obtain a spool of string and mosquito netting (we used Trekmates Mosquito Box Net- Double). Begin to assemble the enclosure by placing four corner pieces on the ends of each bamboo piece to make a rectangular frame of dimensions 6 ft. x 8 ft. Once the frame is complete place the center piece in the middle. Take a piece of string and put it through the groove in the corner piece and out the hole of the corner piece. Feed the same piece of string through the two diagonal holes in the center piece. Bring the same string to the corner piece directly across and string it through the groove and up the hole of the center piece. Loop the string around and tie it tight so as to cause tension. Repeat this process on the other diagonal pieces to create an "X" shape. This will keep the base from falling a part. Next, take two pieces of bamboo and tie them together to make a 12 foot arch. Repeat this process with the two remaining pieces of bamboo and make an arch 13 feet long.
Place the ends of the 12 foot arch into the holes in the corner piece diagonally. Do the same with the 13 foot arch. This will create an "X" with the arches and make the arches support one another. Finally, slip your mosquito net over your structure and the nodes of the bamboo will keep it from slipping. Make sure to tuck the net under the frame to eliminate the access of mosquitoes. To get into the enclosure one can simply just lift the net from under the frame and slip in. This project is sponsored by the RWJUHH Experimenatal Pathology Department-Mentored Research program -"Design challenge".

author: Sum26

description.text:
This is a mount I made to attach my Proxxon IBS/E to the Shapeoko 2. It places the spindle down and away from the Z-axis carriage to maximize the Z travel. Z max is now possible without colliding with the motor mount, and Z min places the chuck 45mm from the wasteboard.
The shape conforms to the original aluminum mount piece to use it as reinforcement, and also latches onto the Z carriage plate itself.
I printed a completely solid piece and it's definitely sturdy enough for cutting soft materials. If I make a top mount I'll certainly post it here. Enjoy!
See Instructions tab for mounting hardware.

You'll need 2 M5 25mm socket head screws to mount this through the center holes of the original aluminum mount. I picked up a few from Home Depot:
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-M5-32-x-25-mm-Internal-Hex-Socket-Cap-Head-Cap-Screws-3-Pack-37178/202836108
To tighten the spindle to the mount just reuse the long M5 bolts that's intended for the outer holes of the aluminum amount. You'll need an extra M5 nut on the other end.

comments.text:
I made one, but find that it leaves the tool too high off the waste board. The bottom rollers come off the makerslide when the bit is still a few centimeters above the table.
Perhaps I am doing something wrong?
comments.author: dan77062

comments.text: Oh I made it a little high because I normally use another wasteboard above the stock wasteboard, plus I was worried about the part flexing if it extends too low. Just PMed you with a link to the source file, please check. Thx Dan.

description.text: print at any size you w ant but make sure they are proportionate. Make 18 balls, the last few you will have to force in. REAL WORKING

comments.text:
If you are interested in suggestions I can think of a relatively easy way to extend the use of the bearings.
Split the inner and outer bearings into a top and a bottom piece. Join the inner and outer bearing sides so that when the top and bottom piece are pushed together the inner and outer walls are fixed in place.
This is how metal bearings were squeezed together. The balls are sandwiched between a top and a bottom piece.
If you were to do this then we could use metal balls which are plentiful and relatively easy to make.

You can use this model as a hole in the bottom of a beer tap. You just need to merge it with your model as a hole.

• Create a beer tap
  • Download thread model
  • Make model a hole instead of a solid
  • Merge with tap
  • Print and enjoy!
    • I printed it in PLA and it fit a standard tap thread fine. The only downside is the more you take it on and off the more wear and tear it gets.

title: Delta 12" Compound TwinLaser Miter Saw (Model 36-255L) zero clearance insert

description.text: As a learning exercise I designed and printed this insert for my Delta miter saw.  It fits really well, I only slightly had to drill out the small holes, but otherwise it fits like a glove.  I printed this in PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill.  The blade cut its own slot for a zero clearance fit - I'll put my original one back in for non 90 degree cuts.  Note that with my print bed of 200x250mm I had to rotate it diagonally and remove the binder clips so this would fit with barely a millimeter to spare.

author: phuacw

description.text: This christmas tree model comes straight from the laser cutter, ready to assemble. 16cm (9.5 inches) high, this is an ideal christmas decoration for your home, workshop or makerspace; it's really quick to cut and slots together with no glue. See also: def-proc.co.uk/blog/2012/laser-cut-christmas-trees/ Update December 2016: changed the licence to CC-BY-SA, so it's clear that commercial reuse not restricted.

Cut the stand from 3mm sheet material. I used mdf, but plywood and perspex should work too. Once cut, the two larger pieces will slot together snugly, but they shouldn't need to be forced. Cut one of each of the Foliage files from green A4 card. 200gsm inkjet/craft card is ideal, but it will still work with paper. Once cut, gently hold the inside of each foliage sheet and pull the edges down, to pull the card into a cone shape that is as tall as the stand. Then place each foliage sheet onto the protruding top of the stand so that they sit over each other and push slot in the star into the slot on the top of the stand to hold the foliage in place. Optional extras: Use a colour other than green â€” there's plenty of choice in artificial trees, so go nuts! This is a quick progect (the foliage sheets take me 2mins 45sec) and the card & mdf is relatively low cost, so this is great for demos or teaching You can print the Foliage files for cutting by hand with a scalpel/craft knife too.

description.text: A simple holder for mounting a glass bed raised by a few millimeters on a Kossel Mini. Suitable for Kossels with 15x15 extrusions. The glass bed shown on this photos has been cut out of recycled 5mm thick window glass, that has been found on the local buyback center. It didn't cost me a buck ;-) Note: The bed will be raised slightly by about 1cm, to have enough clearance for the large thermal fuses.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer thickness

Notes: I used Slic3r with 0.2mm layer thickness and a 0.5mm J-Head nozzle.

• Important: If you're not using a 5mm thick glass bed, adjust the thickness in the OpenSCAD file and export a new STL file.
  • Create a paper template for cutting the glass bed, by measuring the distances inside of the notches.
  • Apply paper template onto glass and draw outlines with a permanent marker. Remove paper template afterwards.
  • Cut glass bed into shape. I used a simple glass cutter and cleaned the edges with sand paper. Some nice tutorials on cutting glass can be found on YouTube (e.g. just search for "cut glass"). Be careful not to cut yourself and always wear protective clothing (safety glasses and work gloves)
  • Slice model and print glass bed holders.
  • Mount 4x glass bed holders with screws and nuts.
  • Insert glas bed into holders.
  • Mount remaining 2x glass bed holders by sliding them in from the sides.
  • That's it. A nice, raised and stable glass bed.

Parts used (BOM)
  • 6x glass bed holders (printed)
  • 6x M3x20mm allen head screws
  • 6x M3 nuts
  • 1x print bed

description.text:
Printed imaged is from Henry_21c's print of this model.
September 2014 Added the fixed canopy from henry_21c, thanks Henry.
I took 3 ED 209 models I found from the sketchup warehouse and rebuilt an Ed. None of them had a good Torso or canopy, so I made my own. 7777773's Ed 209 on here came from the same source ( so you may notice the guns are similar and leg flares.

I did this thingiverse model for a couple of reasons
.
Before anything .. Robocop is one of my favourite all time movies. the new one... not so much, but the original is just such gold. There is a thingiverse member here ProCoPrint3D who is taking models off the sketchup warehouse and charging people for them, which I think is fairly wrong. He charges for a cut up version of his ripped Ed 209 on his website (which I should add is already cut up if you check the various versions of it.. just export from sketchup to OBJ! ) This is here so you you don't have to pay for something you shouldn't
The pieces included are for a standard build, if you want the individual Pieces or STL files, I have included the .Zip also.

These are some really chunky bevel gears for making M8 trans-axles with. Specifically, they let you get away with using one Z motor in Rroofl-style http://reprap.org/wiki/Rroofl designs.

The file will print a set of 4 gears that will work at right angles to each other. Print in standard clear or tinted PLA for maximum wear resistance.
To assemble, thread an M8 nut onto the shaft, push the gear on after it so the nut goes in the gear's cavity. Push a washer on behind it (the bigger the better) and do another nut up close behind. This pinches the gear tightly onto the shaft.

Remove any plastic parts.
Push this part onto the front of the pin.
Reassemble.

title: extruder and heat barrier found at walmart! cheap!

description.text:
i have found out a way to make a heater barrier out of high temp cork found in the hobby isle at walmart stores and at home depot hardware section. video of it working here
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TZ994gv_HaA
and it running at 285C here
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aHnd-BPtAmw

go to walmart in crafts section and look for corks, these corks are temp capable to 300c, and fire retardant, will not catch fire. go to welding section and get a pack of welding rod filaments .6mm, if not. at walmart then home depot. for less that 10.00 you now have enough cork and welding rod filiments to make 6 or more replacement extruders. parts you will also need that can be used again and again. a1 100k or 200k thermistor, and a fiberglass coated ni chrome wire about 5-6inches in length or about 4-5ohms. also you will need 1 m6 nut, and a 1/4 inch hole 1/2 inch washer get 1/8 drill bit and take a tiny piece of tubing and place it thru the drill bit, and reference the welding rod tip, so that 1-2mm of it extends past the drill bit, then with the tubing thur the drill bit, drill into the welding rod, until at reference where the welding rod is drilled into, most likely the welding rod will be clogged with metal pieces. to get rid of those pieces in the .6mm hole, put a piece of plastic filament into the 1/ inch hole you just cut, thread the m6 nut onto the welding rod, and hold that part with a pair of pliers, then using a lighter, heat the copper welding rod, until the plastic starts to melt, then push the plastic thru until it goes thru the hole, then pull back. wait for welding rod to cool, then drill out the plastic. the tiny hole should now be unclogged, or it will be full of plastic that can melt later on... now, hand drill 1/8 inch drill bit all the way thru the center of the cork piece, try to be centered if possible. then on the fat end that goes towards the welding rod piece, drill .4 -.5 inch hole .1 -.15 inches deep, you want it to be deep enough to guide the 1/8 inch hole with the 1/8 inch hole in the welding rod, but you want to form a compressive seal, so don\'t make it more than .15inch or more deep! on the upper end of the cork barrier, use a .24 inch bit to taper the entry into the 1/8 inch hole, then, after that is done, take kapton tape and wrap tightly around the cork, from top to boom and back 2 times around at least. this is because the cork does not have a lot of strength to hold together otherwise. you can use electrical tape if you would like, because the outside of the cork does not get hot enough to melt electrical tape except near the bottom. you may want to use this part to hold the top in place if used on a rapman like i did here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3742 take 1, or 2 1/4 inch hole 1/2 inch wide washers, place beneath the welding rod piece, as in picture, the bold the part into place, as you would a normal ptfe piece with a normal barrel. you just want to make sure that the part forms a seal, so the bottom needs to compress at least a1/10of an inch into the m6 nut, and the cork needs to touch the washers, because otherwise there will not be a good seal and plastic will seep out. also have a piece of plastic filament inside the welding rod holder piece, and the cord, so when it is tightened down the 1/8 inch holes lineup this design allows a very short heating region, I have only tried it with abs, but i can run my extruder all the way up to 285C! - this is my 4th try at the cork extruder, the method i demonstrated here works ok, just because the extruder is copper, you will want to preheat your extruder before you go into a program and use it, also you must file down the end of your filament, otherwise the cork will tear from the inside. downside is the smallest filament is .6mm, i have no idea how long the cork barrier will last. my previous one was not taped on the sides, and blew out when i tried pushing filament thru at a lower temp that what can push at. also this extruder require temp to be about 5 deg c higher to flow correctly.

comments.text: very nice, but the copper is in direct contact with your metal platform and the platform is screwed with big bolts into plastic. So there is not a secured isolation. But nice work.
comments.author: snake233

comments.text: thanks for your interest in this 3+ year old post, but the temp at the end of the rods that connect to the metal part that holds the nozzle never reaches melting temp. I think it is 80-100 degc cooler that the hot end plate. heat does not really travel up that effectively. this design does not however last long, and is only a temp fix, and it does not work with the low glass transition temp of pla. (pla will bend before it gets thru to the extruder).  what did this do for the community. it shows how alternate materials can work for 3d printing, and that some woods can be used near the hot end.
comments.author: snake233

comments.text: Cork has been used as Heat Resistant Material since the Advent of the steam Era and before If you keep it moist it will not Burn. also you can Heat Water to Boiling over a Fire in a Wine skin.... Engineers that made the cnc 3D Printer just have not been told the Propertys of Older matirials you Cannot Pour or Paste Cork so you have to get it right the First time I used to use cork Gaskets in Cars. Tin was just more convenient and cheaper then cork
comments.author: jjhcs1

author: jamesvilleneuve

description.text: A close copy of my wife's violin bridge.  Can be used in an emergency.  You could be a hero and life saver with this one!

The base will have to be shaped to fit the top of your violin.  Print this at 10% fill and it will be 1g heavier than a wooden one.
Use a fine file very lightly to create string guides.  Use an old bridge as a reference.  These guides don't have to be very deep.
The bass side is higher than the treble side.  When installed, the flat side (build platform side) faces the tailpiece and the contoured side toward the fingerboard.

comments.text:
I printed one of these for use on an electric violin, but the feet have an arch on your design, the violin
I have uses a bridge with flat feet. Going to try and make a revision of this with flat feet. Will post a link to it
if I get it done and fitting nicely.
comments.author: Syntax

comments.text: I made six or seven out of PLA on my Prusa i3. Excellent sound quality and has not warped within the last 2 months. Infill was 20% and used Kisslicer for slicing. I am replacing all my violin bridges with these. Only problem is if the finger-board has gone down a little, it would be necessary to print a lower one - sanding down the existing one is quite awkward with 20% infill. An openscad source file would be good.
comments.author: arani

comments.text: Have you actually tested this? I highly doubt this will work. The stresses are quite large. Additionally the bridge is important for the sound quality.I think different infill densities might have better/worse sound qualities
comments.author: bitflusher

comments.text: It's more for an emergency, not for long term. Probably just to keep the sound peg from falling in a sinch.
comments.author: bitflusher

author: JulPal

description.text:
This is a stencil my neighbor asked about. I had printed raised letters in Sketchup, but cutouts were always evil. New strategy made it slick.   
A flat rectangle and the 3D text tool. The catch was that I set the 3D text tool to not filled and not extruded. Placed it on the rectangle and scaled it just the way I wanted. Selected them both and used intersect faces.   
I then drew connections for O's and such or added a small piece to keep the center of the letter in place.
Rocket with four fins and windows

No raft or support required... support is built into the design where required.
For a thin line between rocket stages (at original size) print as follows:
Z-Pause at 33mm and change colour (to black) for 1mm then revert to original colour
Z-Pause again at 52mm and change colour (to black) for 1mm then revert to original colour
Remove designed in base support after printing.

This is a stencil my neighbor asked about. I had printed raised letters in Sketchup, but cutouts were always evil. New strategy made it slick.
A flat rectangle and the 3D text tool. The catch was that I set the 3D text tool to not filled and not extruded. Placed it on the rectangle and scaled it just the way I wanted. Selected them both and used intersect faces.
I then drew connections for O's and such or added a small piece to keep the center of the letter in place.
I only raised the stencil up to 1/32 of an inch. They printed really well and my neighbor is happy as can be. They were adding the logo to a antique cart they were restoring.

Update 26/06/2014
fix the back arms so no support is need, and made legs

working on arms to make a small V-Tail AnyCopter

If you've ever wanted to fly an experiment to the edge of space, this is your chance! PongSat by JP Aerospace is the World's Space Program! A Pongsat is an experiment stuffed inside a ping pong ball, and we fly them for FREE! Sky's (no-- SPACE) is the limit! What will you fly?  
Update: By the way, this is an on-going program, not a one time event. We do routine PongSat flights every few months. The PongSat program itself is several years old, and will likely continue for as long as JP Aerospace is in business. So even though this "thing" was posted a couple years ago, it is still very much alive and well. Make yours today!

• Read the getting started pdf: http://www.jpaerospace.com/pongsat/PongSGuide-n.PDF

  • Create your experiment per the guidelines in the pdf.

  • Cut open a ping pong ball and stuff your experiment inside (or 3D print one using the supplied model for extra geek appeal).

  • Fill out the form on the back page of the pdf from #1.

  • Mail us your PongSat with the form from #4, and we'll fly your experiment on our next flight! Our balloon flights routinely reach an altitude of 90,000 to 100,000 feet!
    • Note: although the PongSat program is focused toward education, anyone anywhere may participate, student or not. The purpose of the program is learning by doing: an opportunity to get hands on with space easily. Also, the model is provided for you to customize for your experiment, such as adding circuit board, switch, and sensor mounts. The only modification not allowed is making the diameter larger than 40mm, at least not without special permission. Links: JP Aerospace home page: http://jpaerospace.com/ JP Aerospace blog: http://jpaerospace.com/blog/ JP Aerospace on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/jpaerospace PongSat home page: http://www.jpaerospace.com/pongsat/index.htm PongSat on Facebook: www.facebook.com/pages/PongSat/250288635034145 PongSat on Space.com: http://www.space.com/17589-pongsat-ping-pong-balls-space-balloon.html PongSat on Wired: http://www.wired.com/design/2012/07/pongsats/ PongSat on NBC: http://dailynightly.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/12/11/15848691-learn-more-about-jp-aerospace?lite

comments.author: juntti99

comments.text: No the vehicle does not get high enough for a pyrotechnic reentry, but it does go into supersonic free fall when the balloon bursts. Typically these flights get up to 80,000-100,000 feet, which is in the stratosphere, and at that altitude the environment is virtually identical to space unless you are moving at hypersonic speeds, i.e. the air is so thin that convective heat transfer doesn't work, cosmic radiation is present, and the sunlight is much stronger than on the ground. If you make an electronic experiment, it will be switched on before takeoff and shipped back to you. Make sure you put a clearly labeled on/off switch on the outside of the pongsat, and keep in mind that the recovery teams likely won't switch it back off again when they recover the vehicle, so design it to turn on and be left on until the battery dies. If you need experiment ideas, read the pongsat guide pdf and read the pongsat page on JPA's website (links are in "thing details"). You could also google pongsat, as some participants have posted about their experiments on various blogs.
comments.author: juntti99

comments.text: I'm thinking of making some sort of radio spectrum monitor to see what kind of signals you could find up  there would that be a problem for the vehicle it would only be a receiver. By the way I'm European so the Imperial system is little more than gibberish to me If it's not to much trouble metric would probably make conversation easier.

comments.text: A receiver is perfectly fine. The two main transmitters on board are 144 MHz and (if equipped) 900 MHz. Transmissions occur once every 15 seconds and last for about a second, so there will be a few seconds of silence on board in between vehicle transmissions.

description.text:
Used to mould fresh wafers into a bowl shape.
Must be made of food-safe material, and preferably covered in cling film before use.

I used this recipe: http://www.skiptomylou.org/2010/07/13/homemade-waffle-cone-and-bowls/ Instructions:
  • Pour small amount of waffle mix onto waffle iron or sandwich press.
  • Cook for 60 seconds or so, until just browning
  • Take off the iron and center on the mandrell, immediately pressing it down with the mould or a glass (I found I had an ikea shot glass exactly the right size)
  • Wait 15-20 seconds, then demould and store in a sealed container
    • Dimensions:
    The bowl it makes is ~40mm inner dia.
    The mandrel base is 80mm dia, 5mm thick.
    The mould is 3mm thick.

These were made to accept 4-40 screws (.112").
The countersunk hole is for nut/lockwasher combo (McMaster #90675A005), which is why I made it circular, to account for the lockwasher, which bites the ABS. If you want to use larger machine screws, try scaling up. There are cylindrical holes in two axis, which I designed for aligning the pieces and glueing them to a surface. I suppose the height could be doubled for an additional set of these tunnels to connect all sides to make a rectangular frame or you could print up a second copy and bolt 'em together if you're feelin lazy. I've already radically changed the design to suit my purposes, so I'll have to revisit this once I've finished the active project.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368375 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=368375
A mounting system with mating parts.  Permanently mount one half, and screw in the other half for a removable framing system.

The tallest piece mounts to a surface/object (via epoxy or 4-40 screw).
The second piece (triangle with ears), mates with the larger piece. Mount any object to the second piece with a screw and you can firmly attach/detach your object to the mounted outer frame. The friction fit is pretty tight (.5mm offset on female groove), so print one and play with it to see how many you think you need. The third (flattest) piece is an optional cap, to keep the assembly from being pushed out from the opposite side.

title: Solid and Smooth 1kg or 5lb reel holder

description.text:
UPDATE: filamentGuideV2 file. ( see 2nd photo for updated part)
3 reasons: 1) I broke a few of the initial filament guides when moving printers around. 2) New width of the part makes for easy sizing of 1kg reel spacing (reel holders fit snug against the guide for perfect distance). 3) Install upside down so when you have prints that max out your Z height, the filament has room to move around without breaking. Enjoy!
If you have made this thing, PLEASE take pictures and post! Thanks.
As more projects pile up on our workbenches, it was time to get the reels mounted to our printers for extra space. Here is a reel holder that is solid enough to hold a fresh 5lb reel but adjustable to also accommodate 1kg reels. It is designed for "Mendel-style" 3D printers that have a 3030 aluminum extrusion on the cross bar. Having the bearings mounted independent of each other provides extremely smooth feeding action.

Print (2) reelHolderV3 and (1) fliamentGuide files.
The shape will lock the reel holders in place on the extrusion and I added a little plastic washer that is built into the part. You can adjust the width to accommodate either 1kg or 5lb reels.
Filament cleaner mounts on the front. The filament cleaner is just a rag with a binder clip but works amazing!
Hardware used:
(3) M5x12
(3) M5 washers
(3) T-nuts for 3030 with M5 tapped hole
(4) M8x30 bolts (M8x25 might be better but this is what I had)
(4) M8 washers
(4) M8 nuts
(4) 608zz bearings (I used these: http://www.vxb.com/page/bearings/PROD/608ZZ10-1)
Total cost w/ material and shipping around $10.

A twisted hexagon . To get a vase version, set the infill and top layers to 0, and set number of perimeters and bottom layers to a suitable wall thickness.
The finished vases are nice for storing nuts and screws for your printer :-) The OpenSCAD model is very easy to edit, to change the hight, twist, scale or using it as part of something else. The STL file is generated with 400 layers of points (thus the name), which should be more precise than any home 3D-printers can print as off now, if you still want more resolution, it is very easy to change that in the OpenSCAD file. I used the following site to quickly generate the coordinates for the hexagon, if you want a different polygon, check it out: http://www.mathopenref.com/coordpolycalc.html

description.text: Ã—1.5 scale japan puzzle

The coins originally created by Ipsec had some problems printing out on Up! Mini printer I am using. The icons in the centers, printed separately, so the coins fell apart into a ring and a logo.  
I loaded the troubled 3 into Blender v2.7 and used a Boolean operation to unite the logo with the coin in one mesh, instead of two meshes intersecting. IPsec's White and Fire coins required no alteration.  
The coins then printed perfectly.   
I painted them with some Reaper paints, and gave them a clear spray finish.  
The coins themselves are actually quite useless when playing. We used them to track the attack and defense values of creatures, but some cards like enlarge, will require 14 coins, and only last one round. However, I did use a coin to mark which of my cards had summoning sickness, which was way better than having the card face down like usual.  
That said, they are a very nice thing to have, and I'll instead put them up on a wall in a picture frame.

Spring-loaded Rod Cover (rc) for Makerbot to keep smooth X rods from rattling and vibrating. I only printed one of these so far, and it SEEMS to reduce noise, but I'll update when I have the other 3 printed and installed.
Update: I printed a second one and installed it. Rattling is not eliminated altogether, although it is quieter. I'll try just wrapping some thin tape on the smooth X rod ends to give them a snug fit in the holes in the plywood body.
Printed with default ReplicatorG 0018 settings, 230 extruder, 120 platform.

comments.author: ChrisGray

description.text:
Few things stress me out more than trying to line up both sides of kapton tape for the Replicator HPB.  Doing it by hand always takes me a dozen tries and 20 minutes to get it flat, creaseless, and without overlaps or gaps. 
However most jigs i found either weren't printable, or weren't particularly helpful. This little guy is easy to print and easy to use.

Print the jig. May need to be rotated to fit nicely on the build plate.
Unfurl some tape, keeping it lined up with the lip on the long side. Wrap some slack around the short end to maintain some grip.
Then just line up the edges of the jig with the build plate, and press down.  now you have a nice straight half of the HPB perfectly taped (helps if you first spritz the bed with windex, to make it easier to push out any bubbles).
Repeat for the other side. As long as you align with the lip on the jig, the two halfs should perfectly line up with no overlap

title: Foam damping foot for 5mm thick panel

description.text:
I create these dampeners for my CTC printer. Now is less noisy and has reduced vibrations. Work great! Print two damp.stl and two dampMirror.stl.
Cut four 25x25mm eva foam pieces and glue it to plastic parts (i found cheap eva adhesive pads on a bazar shop ready to use)
The plywood panels are 5mm thickness so it should work on any printer or structure with 5mm panels.

title: 3D map of Switzerland
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Altimetric map of Switzerland. Data taken from the free dataset DHM200 Source: Swiss Federal Office of Topography. Distributed in compliance with the license point 5h: "Publication of data on the Internet as single static image or within a viewing service, up to a maximum of 500,000 pixels for the purpose of providing information" Please retain the above notice in all derivative works. STL generated with Matlab using surf2solid (Matthew Roughan, http://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/30709) and surf2stl (Bill McDonald, http://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/4512-surf2stl)

Print and enjoy :)
The "smooth" version of the stl was generated with a Laplacian smoothing in Meshlab and looks better IMO.
The plain version represents the original data subsampled to a 2km grid.
